name: wordpress
desc: Deploy WordPress to create a powerful and flexible content management system (CMS) that allows users to build and manage websites with ease. WordPress is widely used for blogging, e-commerce, portfolios, and more, thanks to its extensive themes and plugins.
longDesc:
WordPress is an open-source CMS that enables users to create and manage websites without needing extensive technical knowledge. It is highly customizable and supports a wide range of functionalities through themes and plugins.

**Key Features:**
- **One-Click Deployment:** Quickly set up WordPress using various hosting providers that offer one-click installation options, or deploy using Docker for a more customized setup.
- **Scalability:** Suitable for small personal blogs as well as large enterprise websites, handling high traffic and extensive content management needs.
- **Privacy and Security:** Provides built-in security features, and users can enhance security further with plugins and best practices.
- **API Compatibility:** Supports REST API, enabling developers to integrate with other applications and create custom solutions.
- **Extensive Customization:** Offers thousands of themes and plugins, allowing users to create unique websites tailored to their needs.
useCases:
- **Bloggers:** Use WordPress to create and manage personal or professional blogs with ease.
- **Businesses:** Implement WordPress for corporate websites, showcasing services and products, and enhancing online presence.
- **Educators:** Create educational platforms or e-learning sites, providing resources and materials in an organized manner.
support:
- **Community Forums:** Engage with the WordPress community for support and discussions through the [WordPress Support Forums](https://wordpress.org/support/).
- **Documentation:** Comprehensive guides and user manuals are available at the [WordPress Codex](https://codex.wordpress.org/) and the [WordPress Developer Documentation](https://developer.wordpress.org/) for detailed reference.
- **Troubleshooting Help:** Access the issues section on the [WordPress GitHub Repository](https://github.com/WordPress/WordPress) to report bugs and find community-contributed solutions.

options.name: sites
options.desc: Specification of one or more WordPress sites to serve

options.name: sites.<name>.database.createLocally
options.desc: Create the database and database user locally.

options.name: sites.<name>.database.host
options.desc: Database host address.

options.name: sites.<name>.database.name
options.desc: Database name.

options.name: sites.<name>.database.passwordFile
options.desc: A file containing the password corresponding to database.user.

options.name: sites.<name>.database.port
options.desc: Database host port.
options.type: 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

options.name: sites.<name>.database.socket
options.desc: Path to the unix socket file to use for authentication.

options.name: sites.<name>.database.tablePrefix
options.desc: The $table_prefix is the value placed in the front of your database tables. Change the value if you want to use something other than wp_ for your database prefix. Typically this is changed if you are installing multiple WordPress blogs in the same database. See https://codex.wordpress.org/Editing_wp-config.php#table_prefix.

options.name: sites.<name>.database.user
options.desc: Database user.

options.name: sites.<name>.extraConfig
options.desc: Any additional text to be appended to the wp-config.php configuration file. This is a PHP script. For configuration settings, see https://codex.wordpress.org/Editing_wp-config.php. Note: Please pass structured settings via services.wordpress.sites.‹name›.settings instead.

options.name: sites.<name>.fontsDir
options.desc: This directory is used to download fonts from a remote location, e.g. to host google fonts locally.

options.name: sites.<name>.languages
options.desc: List of path(s) to respective language(s) which are copied from the ‘languages’ directory.

options.name: sites.<name>.mergedConfig
options.desc: Read only representation of the final configuration.

options.name: sites.<name>.package
options.desc: The wordpress package to use.

options.name: sites.<name>.plugins
options.desc: Path(s) to respective plugin(s) which are copied from the ‘plugins’ directory.  These plugins need to be packaged before use, see example.
options.type: (attribute set of path) or (list of path) convertible to it

options.name: sites.<name>.poolConfig
options.desc: Options for the WordPress PHP pool. See the documentation on php-fpm.conf for details on configuration directives.
options.type: attribute set of (string or signed integer or boolean)

options.name: sites.<name>.settings
options.desc: Structural Wordpress configuration. Refer to https://developer.wordpress.org/apis/wp-config-php for details and supported values.

options.name: sites.<name>.themes
options.desc: Path(s) to respective theme(s) which are copied from the ‘theme’ directory.  These themes need to be packaged before use, see example.
options.type: (attribute set of path) or (list of path) convertible to it

options.name: sites.<name>.uploadsDir
options.desc: This directory is used for uploads of pictures. The directory passed here is automatically created and permissions adjusted as required.

options.name: sites.<name>.virtualHost
options.desc: Apache configuration can be done by adapting services.httpd.virtualHosts.

options.name: sites.<name>.virtualHost.acmeRoot
options.desc: Directory for the acme challenge which is PUBLIC, don’t put certs or keys in here. Set to null to inherit from config.security.acme.

options.name: sites.<name>.virtualHost.addSSL
options.desc: Whether to enable HTTPS in addition to plain HTTP. This will set defaults for listen to listen on all interfaces on the respective default ports (80, 443).

options.name: sites.<name>.virtualHost.adminAddr
options.desc: E-mail address of the server administrator.

options.name: sites.<name>.virtualHost.documentRoot
options.desc: The path of Apache’s document root directory. If left undefined, an empty directory in the Nix store will be used as root.

options.name: sites.<name>.virtualHost.enableACME
options.desc: Whether to ask Let’s Encrypt to sign a certificate for this vhost. Alternately, you can use an existing certificate through useACMEHost.

options.name: sites.<name>.virtualHost.enableUserDir
options.desc: Whether to enable serving ~/public_html as /~«username».

options.name: sites.<name>.virtualHost.extraConfig
options.desc: These lines go to httpd.conf verbatim. They will go after directories and directory aliases defined by default.

options.name: sites.<name>.virtualHost.forceSSL
options.desc: Whether to add a separate nginx server block that permanently redirects (301) all plain HTTP traffic to HTTPS. This will set defaults for listen to listen on all interfaces on the respective default ports (80, 443), where the non-SSL listens are used for the redirect vhosts.

options.name: sites.<name>.virtualHost.globalRedirect
options.desc: If set, all requests for this host are redirected permanently to the given URL.

options.name: sites.<name>.virtualHost.hostName
options.desc: Canonical hostname for the server.

options.name: sites.<name>.virtualHost.http2
options.desc: Whether to enable HTTP 2. HTTP/2 is supported in all multi-processing modules that come with httpd. However, if you use the prefork mpm, there will be severe restrictions. Refer to https://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.4/howto/http2.html#mpm-config for details.

options.name: sites.<name>.virtualHost.listen
options.desc: Listen addresses and ports for this virtual host.  This option overrides addSSL, forceSSL and onlySSL. If you only want to set the addresses manually and not the ports, take a look at listenAddresses.

options.name: sites.<name>.virtualHost.listen.*.ip
options.desc: IP to listen on. 0.0.0.0 for IPv4 only, * for all.

options.name: sites.<name>.virtualHost.listen.*.port
options.desc: Port to listen on
options.type: 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

options.name: sites.<name>.virtualHost.listen.*.ssl
options.desc: Whether to enable SSL (https) support.

options.name: sites.<name>.virtualHost.listenAddresses
options.desc: Listen addresses for this virtual host. Compared to listen this only sets the addresses and the ports are chosen automatically.

options.name: sites.<name>.virtualHost.locations
options.desc: Declarative location config. See https://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.4/mod/core.html#location for details.

options.name: sites.<name>.virtualHost.locations.<name>.alias
options.desc: Alias directory for requests. See https://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.4/mod/mod_alias.html#alias.

options.name: sites.<name>.virtualHost.locations.<name>.extraConfig
options.desc: These lines go to the end of the location verbatim.

options.name: sites.<name>.virtualHost.locations.<name>.index
options.desc: Adds DirectoryIndex directive. See https://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.4/mod/mod_dir.html#directoryindex.

options.name: sites.<name>.virtualHost.locations.<name>.priority
options.desc: Order of this location block in relation to the others in the vhost. The semantics are the same as with lib.mkOrder. Smaller values have a greater priority.

options.name: sites.<name>.virtualHost.locations.<name>.proxyPass
options.desc: Sets up a simple reverse proxy as described by https://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.4/howto/reverse_proxy.html#simple.

options.name: sites.<name>.virtualHost.logFormat
options.desc: Log format for Apache’s log files. Possible values are: combined, common, referer, agent.

options.name: sites.<name>.virtualHost.onlySSL
options.desc: Whether to enable HTTPS and reject plain HTTP connections. This will set defaults for listen to listen on all interfaces on port 443.

options.name: sites.<name>.virtualHost.robotsEntries
options.desc: Specification of pages to be ignored by web crawlers. See http://www.robotstxt.org/ for details.

options.name: sites.<name>.virtualHost.servedDirs
options.desc: This option provides a simple way to serve static directories.

options.name: sites.<name>.virtualHost.servedFiles
options.desc: This option provides a simple way to serve individual, static files.  This option has been deprecated and will be removed in a future version of NixOS. You can achieve the same result by making use of the locations.<name>.alias option.

options.name: sites.<name>.virtualHost.serverAliases
options.desc: Additional names of virtual hosts served by this virtual host configuration.

options.name: sites.<name>.virtualHost.sslServerCert
options.desc: Path to server SSL certificate.

options.name: sites.<name>.virtualHost.sslServerChain
options.desc: Path to server SSL chain file.

options.name: sites.<name>.virtualHost.sslServerKey
options.desc: Path to server SSL certificate key.

options.name: sites.<name>.virtualHost.useACMEHost
options.desc: A host of an existing Let’s Encrypt certificate to use. This is useful if you have many subdomains and want to avoid hitting the rate limit. Alternately, you can generate a certificate through enableACME. Note that this option does not create any certificates, nor it does add subdomains to existing ones – you will need to create them manually using security.acme.certs.

options.name: webserver
options.desc: Whether to use apache2 or nginx for virtual host management. Further nginx configuration can be done by adapting services.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>. See services.nginx.virtualHosts for further information. Further apache2 configuration can be done by adapting services.httpd.virtualHosts.<name>. See services.httpd.virtualHosts for further information.
